entries.content: When a client says 'I need to think about it,' acknowledge their position and ask 'What specifically do you need to think about?' to uncover underlying concerns.
Listen actively to the objection and validate the client's perspective before responding.
Use the client's language when reflecting their objection back to them to show understanding.
Reframe a stated objection into a question to clarify the client's real hurdle.
If the client says 'I can get it cheaper elsewhere,' pivot the conversation to value, quality, or unique benefits that justify the price.
Address 'no money' objections by exploring financing options, payment plans, or phasing solutions.
Handle 'no time' objections by focusing on how the solution saves time or improves efficiency for the client.
Use the 'feel, felt, found' framework: 'I understand how you feel, other clients have felt that way, but what they found was...' to overcome common objections.
Isolate the objection: Confirm with the client if resolving this one specific issue would allow them to move forward.
Ask clarifying questions to get to the root cause of an objection rather than just accepting it at face value.
Turn an objection into a discussion point or question back to the client to keep the conversation flowing.
Maintain a calm and confident tone when addressing objections; don't become defensive.
entries.notes: Tone and composure are key to effective objection handling.

entries.content: Don't interrupt the client when they are stating an objection.
Confirm you've fully understood the objection before attempting to respond to it.
Handle the 'need to talk to someone else' objection by asking about their decision process and what information the other person will need.
